title: 114_hr4287
content: The "Wireless Tax Fairness Act of 2015" may be cited as the official title of this Act. Key findings are outlined in Section 2. Congress finds it appropriate to use its enforcement authority under the 14th Amendment and the commerce clause to prevent discrimination against mobile service providers and consumers through excessive taxes and burdens. This is in response to a history of discriminatory taxation faced by the industry. The Railroad Revitalization and Regulatory Reform Act of 1976 serves as a model for federal legislation to prevent discriminatory taxes on mobile service providers and consumers. This action is necessary to ensure a fair and consistent remedy for all parties involved. The Railroad Revitalization and Regulatory Reform Act of 1976 serves as a model for federal legislation to prevent discriminatory taxes on mobile service providers and consumers. This action is necessary to ensure a fair and consistent remedy for all parties involved. Additionally, a moratorium is in place. The Act prohibits new discriminatory taxes on mobile services, providers, or property for 5 years. Definitions include mobile service as defined by regulations and mobile service property as property used by providers for mobile services. The Act prohibits new discriminatory taxes on mobile services, providers, or property for 5 years. Definitions include mobile service as defined by regulations and mobile service property as property used by providers for mobile services, whether real, personal, tangible, or intangible. Mobile service provider refers to entities selling or providing mobile services. New discriminatory tax is a tax imposed by a State or local jurisdiction on mobile services at a different rate than other services. The Act prohibits discriminatory taxes on mobile services, providers, or property for 5 years. This includes taxes imposed at different rates compared to other services or property. The Act prohibits discriminatory taxes on mobile services, providers, or property for 5 years, unless such taxes were enforced prior to the Act's enactment. The term "State or local jurisdiction" refers to entities with the authority to impose taxes. A "tax" is defined as a charge by a government entity for revenue generation. The term "tax" excludes fees imposed on specific entities for privileges or benefits. It also excludes fees for universal service programs, E-911 systems, and federal programs. The text discusses the rules of construction for determining discriminatory taxes, specifically related to Federal telecommunications relay services and State programs under the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. It emphasizes considering various tax factors in determining discriminatory taxes on mobile services. In determining if a tax on mobile service property is a new discriminatory tax, principles similar to those in the Railroad Revitalization Act of 1976 apply. Exclusions include taxes on specific services, industries, or property types, and a new discriminatory tax does not include a new tax or modification of an existing tax. The new tax on mobile services should not exceed the revenue generated by the previous taxes on mobile services, providers, or property. The new tax on mobile services must not exceed the revenue from previous taxes on mobile services, providers, or property. Local jurisdiction taxes require voter approval, 90 days' notice to providers, and must be collected from customers. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. The district courts of the United States have jurisdiction to grant injunctive relief, interim equitable relief, and declaratory judgments to prevent acts in violation of this Act. Jurisdiction is not exclusive, burden of proof lies with the party seeking relief, and relief can be granted against a tax. The district courts have jurisdiction to grant relief against discriminatory or excessive taxes under this Act, preventing the imposition of the unfair portion as determined by the court. The GAO will conduct a study. The Comptroller General will conduct a study over a 5-year period to assess the impact of local and State taxes on mobile services costs for consumers. A report will be submitted to the House and Senate Judiciary Committees within 6 years, detailing the study's results. The Comptroller General will submit a report to the House and Senate Judiciary Committees within 6 years, including recommendations for changes to laws and regulations related to the study's results.
